rounds.observation:
You are Player 0 in the Negotiation Game.
You have some resources, and your task is to trade such that the total value of your resources increases.
The resources and associated values you currently have are:
	+ [Wheat]   Qty: 6    Value: 6
	+ [Wood]    Qty: 13   Value: 9
	+ [Sheep]   Qty: 17   Value: 12
	+ [Brick]   Qty: 10   Value: 29
	+ [Ore]     Qty: 24   Value: 38
At each turn, you can talk to your opponent and make a trade offer.
Use the following special tokens for actions:
  - '[Offer: 3 Sheep, 2 Ore -> 5 Brick, 2 Sheep]': [Offer: Offered Resources -> Requested Resources]
  - '[Accept]': To accept an incoming offer.
  - '[Deny]': To deny an incoming offer (default).
The game lasts for 10 turns in total.
rounds.response:
Current tally – Personal totals (value):

Wheat   6 ( 6)
Wood   13 ( 9)
Sheep  17 (12)
Brick  10 (29)
Ore    24 (38)  
Current value = 94

I want to upgrade my position in Wheat and/or Wood while keeping losses elsewhere minimal. Brick at 2.9-worth-per-card and Ore at 1.58-worth-per-card are my “expensive” resources; I can afford to lose a small number of them if the return in Wheat/Wood is big enough.

A quick sanity check: any 2 Bricks = 5.8 points, roughly 1 Wood (0.69) + 1 Sheep (0.70) + 0.7 Wheat – so giving away 2 Bricks for even 3 cards of common resources is marginally good if those 3 cards are useful type-Changers (e.g., Wood/Wheat).

I decide to start by asking my opponent, in chat, what he is especially looking for, and at the same time float an initial feeler-offer.

[Message] Player-0: Hey, nice to meet you! I’m currently heavy on Ore and Brick. Could you use some? What are you short of?

[Offer: 3 Ore, 2 Brick -> 6 Wood, 1 Wheat]

rounds.response:
I'll reflect on the last round before deciding my next move.

- Value of the deal I proposed (to me): –(3×38 – 6×9 – 1×6) = –(114 – 54 – 6) = –54; I expected Player 1’s net gain to offset that.
- I got a [Deny] (expected—he had little reason to give up 6 Wood).

I still have:
 Wheat 6, Wood 13, Sheep 17, Brick 10, Ore 24.

What can Player 1 reasonably want, and what will help me?
Brick is my scarcest product (29 value each), Wood is plentiful (9 value).  
Offering more Brick could be persuasive.

I also note I have extra Sheep and Ore. I value them at 12 and 38, but if the combination brings me even‐value goods I’m happy.

Proposal: 4 Wood (low value), 3 Brick (moderate) for 2 Wheat (needed for variety) plus 1 Sheep (I get rid of surplus) and 3 Wood (necessary to hit fairness).

Cleaner phrasing:

[Offer: 4 Wood, 2 Brick -> 2 Wheat, 1 Sheep, 3 Wood]

To be explicit: I’m giving 6 value units of Wood plus 58 value units of Brick (total 64) and receiving 12 value units of Wood plus 12 value of Sheep and 12 value of Wheat (total 36). That net-gains ~28 to me, giving Player 1 new flexibility.

(If protocol insists strict left → right grammar we can restate the same.)

[Offer: 4 Wood, 2 Brick -> 2 Wheat, 1 Sheep, 3 Wood]

rounds.response:
It’s currently Turn 3 – time to re-evaluate and make a new deal that Player 1 might accept BEFORE the turn ends.

1. Current endowments
- Player 0: 6 Wheat (6), 13 Wood (9), 17 Sheep (12), 10 Brick (29), 24 Ore (38)  
- Valuation table
  Wheat 1 → 6 pt  
  Wood 1 → 9 pt  
  Sheep 1 → 12 pt  
  Brick 1 → 29 pt  
  Ore 1 → 38 pt  

2. Rejection log shows P1 will NOT trade you Wood/Wheat at the prices you last offered.

3. Most-overstocked resources (relative to their value-point density):
   Wood (9 pt each) and Sheep (12 pt each) = lowest “return-per-card” for you.

4. Highest-value target = Brick (29 pt each).  
   You have 10 Brick; P1 presumably values it _less_ than 29.

Logical step: dangle the resource that matters to P1, offer Sheep or Wood at a discount, and lure Brick/Ore back.  
Safest deal = fewer Ores given away.

Offer:
3 Sheep, 3 Wood → 2 Brick, 1 Ore

Cost to you:  
3 Sheep (36) + 3 Wood (27) = 63 pt

Gain to you:  
2 Brick (58) + 1 Ore (38) = 96 pt

Net value swing : +33 pt for you.

P1 gets low-density Sheep & Wood (30 pt of face value) for 2 high-value cards; if they want to reduce brick/ore load that may tempt them.

I now send the offer:

[Offer: 3 Sheep, 3 Wood -> 2 Brick, 1 Ore]

rounds.response:
I’ve re-examined my earlier, higher-value offers and now see value in `Brick` (29) and low-value surplus in `Wood` (9).  
I’m willing to trade away more `Wood` for a modest Brick gain – even a 1-Brick profit improves my total value.

[Offer: 7 Wood, 1 Sheep -> 2 Brick, 1 Wheat]

rounds.response:
My turn is coming up—let’s look at the numbers quickly.

My current totals:
- Wheat: 6 (value 6)  
- Wood: 13 (value 9)  
- Sheep: 17 (value 12)  
- Brick: 10 (value 29)  
- Ore: 24 (value 38)

Player 1 just proposed:  
[5 Wheat, 2 Sheep → 7 Wood, 1 Sheep]

Value check (for me):
- What I’d give up: 5 Wheat (5*3 = 15) + 2 Sheep (2*3 = 6) → total value lost = 21  
- What I’d receive: 7 Wood (7*0.7 ≈ 4.9) + 1 Sheep (3) → total value gained ≈ 7.9

That’s a net loss of ~13 units of value. Not acceptable.

[Deny]

rounds.response:
Let me carefully read the rules again.  
- Our goal is to end with higher point-value in resources than we started with.  
- Player 1 never makes a multi-item offer – the statements“I made no new trade offer” occur after every one of my attempts.  
- The one time they *did* make a formal offer (`5 Wheat+2 Sheep for 7 Wood+1 Sheep`) was so lopsided against me (-23 net) that rejecting it was already optimal.  
- We are now at Turn 8 (game ends after Turn 10).  With only two turns left, any long bargaining sequence is impossible – I have to post an **obviously beneficial trade in this very turn**, otherwise no deal will occur.

My current holdings (values):

Wheat 6(6) Wood 13(9) Sheep 17(12) Brick 10(29) Ore 24(38)  
Total value at this moment: 6+9+12+29+38 = 94

Best “advertisement” trade for a partner who is probably wood-poor is to swap away some of my plentiful **Ore** (38 points total) in exchange for relatively few of their **Wood** and **Brick**, whose value is lower per card (though I need more brick for later turns).  By keeping the amounts small I make it easy for them to see “free” value gain on their side.

[Offer: 3 Ore -> 3 Wood, 1 Brick]

0.reason: Same change in inventory value for all players. Draw.

1.reason: Same change in inventory value for all players. Draw.
